What Hb values would prompt you to diagnose anemia in this age group?
questions.explanation:
Anaemia in a preschool child is defined as a hemoglobin level of <11 g/dL. Preschool age is defined as 2 to 5 years. 742

questions.question:
Question 2: A 7-year-old child is brought to the pediatric OPD by his parents with complaints of excessive 
sleepiness, and poor scholastic performance. On examination, the child has pallor involving 
the tongue, conjunctiva, and nail beds. A flow murmur is heard upon auscultation. Which of 
the following is the most likely cause of the underlying disease?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical signs and symptoms are suggestive of anemia. Acquired hypoproliferative 
anemia, is the most common cause of anemia in children among the given options. Iron-deficiency anemia (which is classified as an acquired hypoproliferative anemia) is the most 
common cause of anemia in children and adults worldwide. Iron deficiency is also the most 
common nutrient deficiency worldwide.

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following statements is true regarding iron?

options.a: Breast milk has higher iron content than cow's milk.
options.b: Cow's milk has higher oral bio-availability of iron than breast milk.
options.c: Introduction of cow's milk at 5 months of age decreases the risk of iron deficiency.
options.d: Cow's milk protein can cause chronic intestinal blood loss in infants.

questions.explanation:
Exposure to whole cow’s milk protein can cause chronic intestinal blood loss in infants. Therefore, 
the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) recommends delaying the introduction of cow's milk in 
infancy and limiting it to <700 mL/day. Both cow's milk and breast milk have the same iron content (0.1mg/dL). The bioavailability of breast milk iron is 2-3 times higher than cow's milk iron. Exclusive breastfeeding until 6 months of age and complementary feeding with iron-rich foods 
thereafter reduces the risk of iron-deficiency anemia in infants.

questions.question:
Question 5: A child who was diagnosed 3 months back with iron deficiency anemia presents with low 
hemoglobin despite being on oral iron therapy. What is the most likely cause for the 
non-responsiveness that you should consider in your differential?

options.c: Occult blood loss from parasitic infestations.

questions.explanation: Poor compliance is the most likely cause of non-responsiveness to oral iron therapy. Differential diagnosis of microcytic anemia that fails to respond to oral iron: • Poor compliance (most common cause) • Incorrect dose or formulation • Malabsorption of administered iron • Ongoing blood loss, including gastrointestinal, menstrual, and pulmonary • Concurrent infection or inflammatory disorder • Concurrent vitamin B12 or folate deficiency • Diagnosis other than iron deficiency • Thalassemias • Hemoglobins C and E disorders • Anemia of chronic disease • Lead poisoning • Sickle thalassemias, hemoglobin SC disease • Iron refractory iron-deficiency anemia (IRIDA)

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following tests can be used to screen a newborn with a family history of sickle 
cell disease?
questions.explanation:
High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is used to screen a newborn with a family 
history of sickle cell disease. Option A: Hemoglobin electrophoresis is the confirmatory test for sickle cell anemia Option C: Heel-prick Guthrie test is the neonatal screening test for phenylketonuria. Option D: Tandem mass spectrometry is being used for neonatal screening of inherited 
metabolic disorders. 744 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: Ravi, an adolescent with sickle cell disease presents to the emergency room with chest pain 
and respiratory distress. Pulse oximeter shows 85% saturation in room air. Chest X-ray shows 
new radiodensities. Sputum and blood culture showed no growth. Which of the following are 
used in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute chest syndrome and all of the above are used in 
the management. Acute chest syndrome (ACS) refers to a life-threatening pulmonary complication of sickle cell 
disease. It is diagnosed with the presence of a new radiodensity on chest radiography with any 2 
of the following: • Fever • Respiratory distress • Hypoxia • Cough • Chest pain In this case, the child with sickle cell anemia satisfies the above criteria. He presented with chest 
pain and respiratory distress and his chest X-ray image shows new radiodensities. Most patients with ACS do not have a single identifiable cause. Infection is the most well-known 
etiology, yet only 30% of ACS episodes will have positive sputum or bronchoalveolar culture. The 
most common bacterial pathogens implicated are S. pneumoniae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and 
Chlamydia spp. Oxygen should be supplemented to all patients who demonstrate hypoxia. Blood transfusion is the only method to abort a rapidly progressing episode of ACS. Because of the clinical overlap between pneumonia and ACS, all episodes should be treated 
promptly with antimicrobial therapy, including at least a macrolide and possibly a 
third-generation cephalosporin. Regular use of an incentive spirometer at 10-12 breaths every 2 hours can significantly reduce the 
frequency of subsequent acute chest pain episodes.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 6-year-old boy who is a known case of sickle cell disease presents with acute chest 
syndrome. Which of the following is the drug of choice to reduce such painful crises in the 
future?
questions.explanation:
Hydroxyurea is the drug of choice for reducing painful crises in sickle cell anemia. Hydroxyurea is a myelosuppressive agent that is effective in reducing the frequency of painful 
episodes like dactylitis and acute chest syndrome, decreasing the rate of hospitalization, and 
requirement for blood transfusion. It is safe and well-tolerated in children and infants. Option A: Hydrocodone (opioid) is used in the treatment of pain crisis in sickle cell anemia. Option C: Corticosteroids is one of the first-line therapies for acute idiopathic thrombocytic 
purpura (ITP) with risk factors for bleeding. Option D: Ruxolitinib is the drug of choice for the treatment of polycythemia vera. 745 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 9: Kevin and Anita both have sickle cell traits. They are devastated when they find out both their 
children have sickle cell anemia. Kirti is an active 9-year-old. Kamal is her 3-month-old 
brother. Which of the following prophylactic measures would you not recommend to them?

options.a: Oral penicillin prophylaxis up to 5 years of age in Kamal
options.b: Annual transcranial Doppler ultrasound for Kirti upto age 16
options.c: Annual ophthalmology screening from the age of 10 years in both
options.d: Hydroxyurea prophylaxis regardless of disease severity or symptoms in both

questions.explanation:
Hydroxyurea prophylaxis regardless of disease severity is recommended in children over 9 
months of age. Hydroxyurea can be considered for use in infants between six and nine months 
with symptomatic disease. Oral penicillin VK is recommended until at least 5 years of age. It is continued beyond 5 years of 
age in children with a history of pneumococcal infection. Erythromycin ethyl succinate is used if 
the patient is allergic to penicillin. Pneumococcal and meningococcal vaccinations are 
administered because of the risk of functional asplenia. Transcranial Doppler ultrasound is recommended, starting at age of 2 years. This has lead to 
a decrease in the prevalence of overt stroke among children with sickle cell anemia. Screening 
should occur annually from age 2-16. Annual ophthalmology screening should commence from the age of 10 years to screen for 
retinopathy.

questions.question:
Question 10: Which of the following is responsible for the most common cause of congenital hemolytic 
anemia due to an enzyme deficiency?

options.a: Deficiency of an enzyme in glycolysis pathway
options.b: Deficiency of an enzyme in Hexose monophosphate pathway
options.c: Deficiency of an enzyme in Kreb's cycle
options.d: Deficiency of an enzymes in fructose metabolism pathway

questions.explanation:
Deficiency of an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway ie., glucose 6-phosphate 
dehydrogenase deficiency(G6PD Deficiency), is the most common cause of congenital hemolytic 
anemia due to an enzyme deficiency Most common enzymopathies causing hemolytic anemia (in order of most common to least): • Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD) • Pyruvate kinase deficiency • 5' nucleotidase deficiency

questions.question:
Question 11: 736 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis?
questions.explanation:
Rh incompatibility causes immune hydrops fetalis, whereas alpha-thalassemia, parvovirus B19 
infection, and twin-twin transfusion syndrome cause non-immune hydrops fetalis. Hydrops fetalis refers to the abnormal fluid collections in fetal soft tissues and serous 
cavities. Edema, signs of heart failure, and profound intra-uterine anemia are the presenting 
features in the fetus. Other clinical features include marked hepatosplenomegaly, retardation in 
brain growth, hydrocephaly, urogenital and cardiovascular deformities, and extramedullary 
erythropoiesis. Non-immune hydrops fetalis (NIHF) comprises the subgroup of cases not caused by red cell 
alloimmunization (e.g., Rh(D), Kell) Bart's hydrops fetalis (alpha-thalassemia) is caused by the deletion or inactivation of all four 
alpha-globin alleles, leading to a severe deficiency in alpha-globin chains of Hb and to the 746 
Sold by @itachibot production of gamma-4 tetramers (Hb Bart). Hb Bart tetramers have an extremely high oxygen 
affinity and are incapable of effective tissue oxygen delivery. Parvovirus B19 infection can cause fetal anemia, non-immune fetal hydrops, and fetal death.

questions.question:
Question 12: Which of the following statements about abnormal hemoglobins and their mechanisms is 
true?

options.a: HbS is due to substitution of lysine for glutamine in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene.
options.b: HbH is the deletion of three alpha-globin genes.
options.c: Hb Bart is the deletion of all four beta-globin genes.
options.d: HbC is due to substitution of valine for lysine in the 6th position of the beta-globin gene.

questions.explanation:
HbH is the deletion of three alpha globin chains. HbS is due to the substitution of valine for glutamic acid in the 6th position of the beta-globin 
gene (option A). Hb Bart is the deletion of all four alpha-globin genes. (There are only 2 beta-globin genes) (option 
C) HbC is due to the substitution of lysine for glutamic acid in the 6th position of the beta-globin 
gene (option D).

questions.question:
Question 13: A 5-year-old child presented with pallor, massive hepatosplenomegaly, and hemolytic facies. 
Which of the following is the most likely iron profile in this patient?

options.a: Iron - low, Ferritin - low, TIBC-high, TSAT-low
options.b: Iron - high, Ferritin - normal, TIBC-normal, TSAT-normal
options.c: Iron - low, Ferritin - high, TIBC-low, TSAT-low
options.d: Iron - low, Ferritin - low, TIBC-low, TSAT-low

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of thalassemia and the most likely iron profile is iron 
- normal/high, ferritin - normal, total iron - binding capacity (TIBC) - normal, and transferrin 
saturation (TSAT) - normal. Iron- low, ferritin-low, TIBC-high, TSAT-low is seen in iron-deficiency anemia. Iron-low, ferritin-high, TIBC-low, TSAT-low is seen in anemia of chronic disease.

questions.question:
Question 14: A toddler presented with progressive pallor and abdominal distention. On investigations, he 
had low hemoglobin. Which of the following red cell indices can be used to distinguish 
thalassemia from iron deficiency anemia?

options.c: Mean corpuscular volume/ Red blood cell count

questions.explanation:
Mean corpuscular volume/ Red blood cell count (MCV/RBC) also known as Mentzer index can be 
used to distinguish thalassemia from iron-deficiency anemia (IDA). MCV (mean corpuscular volume) and MCH (mean corpuscular hemoglobin) are low in both IDA 
and thalassemia. RBC count may be normal in thalassemia, whereas it is reduced in IDA. A lower 
RBC count in IDA means the denominator is smaller, yielding a greater MCV/RBC ratio. Mentzer index is: • More than 13 in iron-deficiency anemia • Less than 13 in thalassemia

questions.question:
Question 15: A 14-month-old child with Hb 6.3 was undergoing repeated blood transfusions. The last 
transfusion was given in the 9th month. Which of the following investigation is used for a 
definitive diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of repeated transfusion, low hemoglobin level, and target cells in the 
smear are suggestive of thalassemia. Globin gene sequencing is used for its definitive diagnosis. 747 
Sold by @itachibot High-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) is used as a screening test for thalassemia 
(option A). Thalassemia is a hemoglobinopathy that arises due to deficient synthesis of the globin chains. 
Depending on the chain affected, it is classified into -thalassemia and -thalassemia. -thalassemia is caused by point mutations of the -thalassemia gene on chromosome 11, which 
diminish the synthesis of -globin chains. Splicing mutations are the most common cause of (+) 
thalassemia. There is a deficit in the synthesis of HbA with an elevation of HbA2 and HbF levels in 
-thalassemia. Children with severe thalassemia present with distinctive facial features such as 
maxilla hyperplasia, a flat nasal bridge, and frontal bossing. Other manifestations include 
pathologic bone fractures, significant hepatosplenomegaly, and cachexia. Blood smears show marked anisocytosis, poikilocytosis, and microcytic hypochromic anemia. 
Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. A radiographic 
image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance. Hb Electrophoresis and high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) are used as screening 
tests for thalassemia. DNA diagnosis to detect -thalassemia mutations is used for definitive 
diagnosis. The Mentzer index is the ratio of MCV to RBC count. It is used to differentiate between 
iron-deficiency anemia and -thalassemia trait. The Mentzer index is <13 in thalassemia minor 
syndrome. Transfusions are administered every 3-4 weeks to maintain a pretransfusion hemoglobin level of 
9.5-10.5 g/dL. Transfusion-induced hemosiderosis is a significant complication in 
transfusion-dependent thalassemia. Iron deposition occurs in the liver, endocrine organs, and 
heart, resulting in complications including hypothyroidism, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism, 
growth hormone deficiency, hypoparathyroidism, diabetes mellitus, heart failure, and 
arrhythmias. The image below shows thalassemic facies and crew cut appearance on X-ray: 748 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 16: You see a child in the hematology unit who has developed anemia which is progressive along 
with cardiac decompensation requiring transfusion. He is in the latter half of infancy. You 
suspect transfusion-dependent thalassemia. Which of the following electrophoresis pattern is 
seen here?
questions.explanation:
HbA=0%, HbA2=5%, HbF=95% is seen on hemoglobin electrophoresis in transfusion-dependent 
thalassemia. Given clinical picture where the child becomes symptomatic during the second 6 months of life 
requiring transfusion is suggestive of beta-thalassemia major or transfusion-dependent 
thalassemia. • Normal pattern- HbA=95%, HbA2=3.5%, HbF =1.5% • Beta-thalassemia trait- HbA=90%, HbA2=5%, HbF=5% • Beta-thalassemia intermedia- HbA=45%, HbA2=5%, HbF=50% Alpha- and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of 
alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively. This leads to precipitation of the excess 
(unpaired) chains, interfering with red blood cell (RBC) production and survival.Disease severity 
is inversely correlated with the number of functioning globin chains.Each individual carries 2 
beta-chain genes and 4 alpha-chain genes.

questions.question:
Question 17: 738 
Sold by @itachibot You are given the following x-ray in the viva session. Which of the following is the likely 
reason behind this abnormal appearance?
questions.explanation:
Crew-cut or hair-on-end appearance on X-ray imaging of the skull is due to extramedullary 
hematopoiesis, which is seen in thalassemia. Ineffective erythropoiesis leads to extramedullary hematopoiesis, which causes the widening of 
the diploic space, thereby causing the thickening of trabeculae. This results in the classical 
crew-cut or hair-on-end appearance on x-ray imaging of the skull. Extramedullary 
hematopoiesis also leads to hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged and distorted bony prominences 
over the face, leading to the characteristic chipmunk facies in thalassemia. 749 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: You are evaluating a 4-year-old child with ß-thalassemia major. He has been on chronic 
transfusion therapy since the age of 1 year. He has developed transfusion-induced iron 
overload. The child has an increased risk of developing which of the following infections?
questions.explanation:
Thalassemic children with transfusion-induced iron overload are at an increased risk of infections 
with Yersinia enterocolitica. Iron excess immunologically compromises the host and greatly enhances yersinial growth. Streptococcus pneumoniae (option A), Mycoplasma pneumoniae (option 
B) , and Chlamydia species (option D) are the common organisms causing infections that 
predispose to acute chest syndrome in sickle cell anemia.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is true about Diamond Blackfan Anemia?

options.a: Short stature, craniofacial abnormalities, and triphalangeal thumb are common features.
options.b: Peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anemia.
options.c: Bone marrow failure includes erythroid, myeloid and megakaryocytic lineages.

questions.explanation:
Short stature, craniofacial abnormalities, and triphalangeal thumb are common features is the 
true statement regarding Diamond–Blackfan anemia (DBA). Features of DBA (congenital hypoplastic anemia): • Autosomal dominant inheritance. • Macrocytosis without hypersegmented neutrophils or other megaloblastic features. • Reticulocytopenia. • Absent RBC precursors in the otherwise normally cellular bone marrow. Other lineages are 
unaffected. • Craniofacial anomaly is the most common congenital anomaly seeen. • Hypertelorism, snub nose, and high-arched palate seen. • Thumb abnormalities- flattening of the thenar eminence and triphalangeal thumb • Short stature Treatment: Corticosteroids, chronic red cell transfusions, and hematopoietic stem cell 
transplantation. Image showing triphalangeal thumb: 750 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 20: You see a neonate undergoing phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia. Blood workup revealed 
the presence of a hemolytic picture along with spherocytes and polychromatophilic 
reticulocytes. MCV is low normal along with elevated MCHC. There was a similar history of 
hemolytic anemia in the mother. The pedigree analysis points towards an autosomal 
dominant mode of inheritance. The most likely genetic mutation seen in this case is?
questions.explanation:
The Ankyrin gene mutation is the most likely genetic mutation seen in the given case of 
autosomal-dominant hereditary spherocytosis (HS). Hemolytic manifestation causing indirect hyperbilirubinemia requiring phototherapy or blood 
transfusion in infancy with positive family history and typical laboratory findings is suggestive of 
HS. History of blood transfusions in later life and not infancy is used to classify the severity of the 
disease. • Most common mode of inheritance of HS- autosomal dominant • Most common gene mutation in autosomal-dominant HS- ankyrin > Band 3 • Most common gene mutation in autosomal-recessive HS- spectrin • Most severe form of HS- spectrin (recessive) Classification of the severity of HS is based on the requirement of blood transfusion in later life 
and not during infancy. RBC Membrane-Cytoskeleton disorders 751

questions.question:
Question 21: An 11-year-old child, born out of consanguineous marriage developed signs and symptoms of 
hemolytic anemia and progressive ataxia. He is a known case of retinitis pigmentosa and also 
had symptoms of fat malabsorption. A peripheral smear of the child is shown. What is the 
likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical features along with the peripheral smear showing acanthocytes make the 
diagnosis of abetalipoproteinemia more likely. Abetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive hemolytic disorder in which acanthocytosis is 
associated with fat malabsorption, progressive ataxia, and retinitis pigmentosa. Acanthocytes or spur cells are spiculated red cells with a few projections of varying size and 
surface distribution. The most significant associations include abetalipoproteinemia and severe 
liver disease. Note: Do not confuse acanthocytes with echinocytes or burr cells. They appear with multiple small 
projections that are uniformly distributed on the red cell surface. It is a universal feature of 
uremia. 753 
Sold by @itachibot Image: The peripheral smear below shows regularly spaced, smoothly rounded crenulations, 
which are characteristic of a burr cell. Peripheral smear in other options: Hemolytic uremic syndrome (option A); Numerous schistocytes and nucleated RBCs with 
extremely low platelets: Glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (option B); bite cells or degmacytes or blister cells. 
In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz 
bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen. The image below shows bite cells represented by blue arrows, black arrows represent burr cells: 754 
Sold by @itachibot Hereditary stomatocytosis (option C); Numerous stomatocytes (Uniconcave cup 
with mouth-shaped area of central pallor), caused by missense mutation in band 3 or AEP

questions.question:
Question 22: A 12-year-old child is receiving iron and folic acid supplements under the Weekly Iron and 
Folic Acid Supplementation (WIFS) Programme. Which of the following is true about this 
program?

options.a: It was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.
options.b: It is meant exclusively for adolescent school girls between 10-19 years of age.
options.c: It exclusively covers government schools in rural India.
options.d: It recommends that administration of 50 mg of elemental iron.

questions.explanation:
Weekly Iron Folic acid Supplementation (WIFS) was launched by the Ministry of Health and 
Family Welfare is the true statement among the given options. Salient features of Weekly Iron Folic acid Supplementation (WIFS): i. Objective of Weekly Iron Folic acid Supplementation (WIFS): To reduce the prevalence and 
severity of anemia in the adolescent population (10-19 years). ii. Target groups 755 
Sold by @itachibot • School-going adolescent girls and boys in 6th to 12th class enrolled in 
government/government-aided/municipal schools • Out-of-school adolescent girls iii. Intervention • Administration of supervised weekly iron-folic acid supplements of 60 mg elemental iron and 
500 g folic acid by using a fixed-day approach • Screening of target groups for moderate/severe anemia and referring these cases to an 
appropriate health facility • Biannual de-worming (albendazole 400 mg), six months apart, for the control of helminthic 
infestation • Information and counseling for improving dietary intake and for taking actions for prevention of 
intestinal worm infestation

questions.question:
Question 23: A toddler is brought by his mother with complaints of poor feeding, lethargy, and chronic 
diarrhea for the past 4 months. Upon clinical examination, the child has pale conjunctiva and 
is tachycardic. Blood workup reveals low hemoglobin and smear shows macrocytosis, 
anisopoikilocytosis, and large neutrophils with hyper-segmented nuclei. Serum homocysteine 
levels are elevated and methylmalonate levels are normal. Bone marrow shows erythroid 
hyperplasia. Which of the following is true about this condition?

options.a: Lactate dehydrogenase levels in serum is low.
options.b: Folate-deficient mother's give birth to infants with folate deficiency.
options.c: Methylenetetrahydrofolate (MTHFR) deficiency is associated with megaloblastic anemia.
options.d: Goat’s milk fed infants are more likely to develop this disease

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario along with the megaloblastic picture elevated homocysteine levels, and 
normal methylmalonate levels are suggestive of folate deficiency anemia. Goat’s milk is deficient in folate. So goat milk-fed infants are likely to develop folate deficiency 
anemia. Human breast milk, infant formulas, and pasteurized cow’s milk provide adequate 
amounts of folic acid. In folate deficiency anemia, lactate dehydrogenase levels in serum are elevated. Folate-deficient 
mothers do not give birth to infants with folate deficiency because there is a selective transfer of 
folate to the fetus via the placental folate receptors. Methylenetetrahydrofolate (MTHFR) deficiency is the most common inborn error of folate 
metabolism, and severe cases can produce neurologic and vascular complications; there is no 
associated megaloblastic anemia. Malnutrition is the most common cause of folate deficiency in children. Note: Both homocysteine and methylmalonate levels are elevated in B12 deficiency anemia.

questions.question:
Question 24: A child presents with megaloblastic anemia that is unresponsive to vitamin C, vitamin B12, 
and folic acid, but responsive to uridine. What do you suspect?
questions.explanation:
Orotic aciduria is to be suspected in this child. Megaloblastic anemia that is responsive to uridine 
is consistent with orotic aciduria. Orotic aciduria is a rare inborn error of metabolism in children. A defect in the pyrimidine 
synthesis pathway results in the failure of conversion of orotic acid to uridine. Supplementation of vitamin B12, folate, and vitamin C rules out the more common nutritional 
causes of megaloblastic anemia. Thiamine deficiency (option A) and anemia due to liver disease (option B) do not respond to 
uridine. 756 
Sold by @itachibot Pernicious anemia (Option C) responds to treatment with vitamin B12. 757 
Sold by @itachibot
